candidates.title: Fixed docsrs flags in Cargo.toml
candidates.body: Current build [fails](https://docs.rs/crate/curve25519-dalek/4.0.0-pre.3/builds/700411) because `simd_backend` was accidentally listed as a feature. This should fix it, but I haven't tested it myself.

candidates.title: Merge `release/4.0` into `main`
candidates.body:
Also bumps version to `4.0.0-pre.3`.

This will say in the README that the current beta is `4.0.0-pre.3`, so we should probably `cargo publish` right after the merge.

candidates.title: Change `Scalar::from_canonical_bytes` to return `CtOption`
candidates.body:
~~*NOTE: includes #470 which should be merged first*~~ Merged!

This is helpful for implementing `ff::PrimeField::from_repr`.

Also changes `Scalar::is_canonical` to return `Choice`.

candidates.title: Use `CryptoRngCore` trait
candidates.body:
This is a convenience/marker trait for types which impl `CryptoRng` + `RngCore` which makes the type signatures a little more readable.

It was introduced in `rand_core` v0.6.4 (now pinned as the minimum version)

candidates.title: Fixes `curve25519_dalek_bits` defaults for cross and wasm
candidates.body:
As discussed in #456 ~~this sets well known defaults for:~~
 ~~`cfg(target_family = "wasm")`~~ and ~~`cfg(target_arch = "arm")`~~

~~By setting the 64 bit serial arithmetric via `cfg(curve25519_dalek_bits = "64")`~~

EDIT: I've used platforms crate via env TARGET to determine the actual cross target and this now fixes build.rs only.

candidates.title: Remove `std` feature
candidates.body:
All of the existing usages of `std` can be replaced with `alloc`.

They are legacy usages from before when liballoc was stabilized.

candidates.title: Use `--cfg curve25519_dalek_backend` to select backend
candidates.body:
Crate features are intended to be additive, whereas only 1-of-N possible backends can be selected.

Features can also be activated by transitive dependencies, which leads to a problem of different dependences selecting conflicting backends. Using `--cfg` instead moves all backend selection control to the toplevel executable.

This commit switches to the following RUSTFLAGS to enable backends:

- `--cfg curve25519_dalek_backend="fiat"`: uses `fiat-crypto` backend
- `--cfg curve25519_dalek_backend="simd"`: uses nightly-only SIMD backend

candidates.title: Updates to README
candidates.body:
[README Rendered](https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/curve25519-dalek/blob/4a687c9f8fd2549f7aa0f882e291038b23366069/README.md)

This subsumes #443 (will add @pinkforest as coauthor). This:

* Reorders some things in the README
* Explains semver policy
* Specifies feature flags and backends more explicitly
* Removes `nightly` from the CI bc that didn't belong there
* Adds @pinkforest to thankyou list (@pinkforest plz tell me if there is a specfic name you want there)

As proposed in #442 moves `rand_core` as optional feature

This still gets used via dev-dependencies and depending on feature selection tests uses API impl by proxy or mock.

candidates.title: Docs cleanup
candidates.body: Merged to the wrong branch in #439. Merging to `release/4.0` now. This should not cause any errors.

candidates.title: Migrate docs to docs.rs and fix backend docs gen
candidates.body:
I've tested backend doc generation here (Some links point to the real crate which needed absolute refs)
https://docs.rs/test-curve25519-dalek

```bash
cargo rustdoc --features "simd_backend packed_simd" -- \
 --html-in-header docs/assets/rustdoc-include-katex-header.html \
 --cfg docsrs
```

docsrs feature documents the necessary things in docs.rs - now backend modules get documented

docs.rs does not support documenting pub(crate) so I had to work/around this with:

```rust
// Arithmetic backends (using u32, u64, etc) live here
#[cfg(docsrs)]
pub mod backend;
#[cfg(not(docsrs))]
pub(crate) mod backend;
```

Details: https://docs.rs/project-template/latest/project_template/

Above is needed since some of the required katex renders comes from there.

Some markdown links require absolute paths e.g.

```
[parallel_doc]: https://docs.rs/curve25519-dalek/latest/curve25519_dalek/backend/vector/index.html
```

As this is both used from repo and docs.rs and there is no way to link in docs.rs relatively as docs.rs always includes the crate/version/crate_normalised
docs.rs ensured the katex'ed markdown is rendered correctly into HTML

Also local documentation can be generated as per instructions w/ cargo rustdoc via make doc

I recommend creating a pre-release to ensure all the docs work and see those docs get rendered ok esp on backend even if I have done for testing already in docs.rs by using different crate name.

Using https://github.com/lycheeverse/lychee to check links - TBC

As expected backend/vector is not yet in docs.rs as this is not published yet there

$ lychee README.md 
```
⠁ 6/17 [00:00:00] ████████░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░ ✔ [200] https://img.shields.io/badge/dynamic/json.svg?label=docs&uri=https%3A%2F%2Fcrates.io%2Fapi%2Fv1%2Fcrates%2Fcurve25519-dalek%2Fversions&query=%24.versions%5B0%5D.numIssues found in 1 input. Find details below.

[README.md]:
✗ [404] https://docs.rs/curve25519-dalek/latest/curve25519_dalek/backend/vector/index.html | Failed: Network error: Not Found

🔍 17 Total ✅ 16 OK 🚫 1 Error (HTTP:1)
```

The redirect error below can be ignored - lychee red herring

$ lychee docs/
```
⠤ 15/15 [00:00:08] █████████████████████████ ✗ [ERR] https://software.intel.com/sites/default/files/managed/9e/bc/64-ia-32-architectures-optimization-manual.pdf | Failed: Network error: error following redirect for uIssues found in 1 input. Find details below.

[docs/parallel-formulas.md]:
✗ [ERR] https://software.intel.com/sites/default/files/managed/9e/bc/64-ia-32-architectures-optimization-manual.pdf | Failed: Network error: error following redirect for url (https://software.intel.com/content/www/us/en/develop/download/intel-64-and-ia-32-architectures-optimization-reference-manual.html): too many redirects

🔍 15 Total ✅ 14 OK 🚫 1 Error (HTTP:1)
```

Even the generated doc was fine - all the errors were safe to ignore just deps / red herrings and the above disclaimer getting it published first :)

$ lychee target/doc/
```
🔍 452146 Total ✅ 452081 OK 🚫 65 Errors (HTTP:65)
```

candidates.title: Bump to 0.4.0 criterion
candidates.body:
Fixes #430 and gets rid of the `csv` dependency that will get rid of the `itoa` 0.4 that used `mem::unitialized`
Fixes #431 and switches from unmaintained `serde_cbor` to `ciborium`

candidates.title: Implement simplified backend selection
candidates.body:
As proposed in #414, this commit changes the backend selection approach, introspecting `target_pointer_width` to select `u32_backend` vs `u64_backend` (or `fiat_u32_backend`/`fiat_u64_backend` if the `fiat_backend` feature is enabled).

This helps eliminate the use of non-additive features, and also the rather confusing errors that happen if multiple backends are selected (i.e. thousands of lines of rustc errors).

The selection logic checks if `target_pointer_width = "64"` and uses the 64-bit backend, or falls back to the 32-bit backend otherwise. This means the crate will always have a valid backend regardless of the pointer width, although there may be odd edge cases for exotic platforms which would optimally use the 64-bit backend but have a non-"64" target pointer width for whatever reason. We can handle those cases as they come up.

candidates.title: Remove byteorder
candidates.body:
Instead of having a dependency on `byteorder` use methods from the
standard library(`{to,from}_le_bytes`).

This addresses the concern in #392

candidates.title: Updated to edition 2021
candidates.body: Not sure what the pro/cons are here. Any opinions?

candidates.title: Relax zeroize dependency
candidates.body:
This PR:
* Relaxes `zeroize` to `^1`
* Improves documentation about this crate's MSRV
* Fixes the MSRV tests. Previously they were using the newest deps. But the MSRV should be calculated with respect to the oldest possible deps.

I would like to cut a release soon. According to the MSRV test, our v4.0 will not require an MSRV bump.

candidates.title: implement Zeroize trait on Ristretto curve point types
candidates.body:
This is helpful for hardening some of our cryptographic implementations
that use Ristretto curve points

Please let me know if you would like this done differently, or if there is
some reason you don't want to use `zeroize_derive`. Thank you!

candidates.title: Serial backends w/formally-verified field arithmetic for 32 & 64 bits
candidates.body:
## Contribution

This sets up two non-default serial backends, `fiat_u32_backend`and `fiat_u64_backend`. Those backends use field arithmetic generated in Rust from proofs of functional correctness checked by the Coq theorem prover, as part of [the fiat-crypto project](https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat-crypto). More details can be found [in the fiat-crypto paper](http://adam.chlipala.net/papers/FiatCryptoSP19/).

This Rust code is located in the [fiat-crypto crate](https://crates.io/crates/fiat-crypto) [maintained by fiat-crypto team](https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat-crypto/blob/master/.github/workflows/publish.yml), and the present PR simply provides the plumbing necessary to integrate with curve25519-dalek's backend architecture.

## Motivation

This contribution could offer to curve25519-dalek an opt-in backend providing *a "gold standard" of correctness*, and [already used for this reason in Wireguard, Go, BoringSSL, etc](https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat-crypto/issues/902). Dalek developers could also use these backends as a *fuzzing target*, in order to check the correctness upcoming optimizations of the serial code.

## Performance

The performance is lower, but within a single digit of the existing basic operations, and only rises to a ~15% slowdown on composite operations.

https://gist.github.com/huitseeker/d3c7a30fa90fdb43d2815eb4b63a7205

## Maintenability

The backends collectively comprise less than [600 SLoC](https://gist.github.com/huitseeker/57819eb28f3749d62f1acbd48e7ed969). They reuse the scalar and constant definitions to offer a minimal code increment.

The fiat-crypto project [already runs the curve25519-dalek unit tests on the fiat_u64 backend as part of its CI](https://github.com/mit-plv/fiat-crypto/blob/master/etc/ci/test-fiat-rust-curve25519-dalek.sh). Hence the probability that it would break this backend is very low. I would be happy to contribute the few lines of adjustments necessary there to make it run on the fiat_u32 backend as well, should the present PR be merged.

candidates.title: Update rand_core to 0.6
candidates.body:
https://github.com/rust-random/rand/blob/master/rand_core/CHANGELOG.md
This new version makes using rand_core on wasm seamless (thanks to the update of getrandom to v0.2)
The crate compiles well with this PR, but since some `rand_core` traits are publicly exposed in this crate's API, this is strictly speaking a breaking change.

candidates.title: Elligator2 mapping for curve25519
candidates.body:
This present PR:
- can be seen as a more conservative variant of PR #326 (it performs no double mapping), 
- implements the vanilla Elligator2 mapping (matching the [draft RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-irtf-cfrg-hash-to-curve-10.html) short of the `expand_message_xmd` expansion¹)
- is, as such, subject to the known distribution biases of Elligator2 (see #326 and https://eprint.iacr.org/2014/043 )

While I'm a fan of Ristretto and would definitely advocate for its use over mapping-to-curve25519 in most situations, this present mapping is still useful in cases where compatibility with other libraries is required — the present mapping is compatible with the one performed in [libsignal](https://github.com/signalapp/libsignal-protocol-c/blob/master/src/curve25519/ed25519/additions/elligator.c) and passes its test vectors.

¹: While this uses an HKDF, I'm happy to attach an implementation of `expand_message_xmd` (here for, essentially, domain separation) should it be requested.

Fixes #188

https://github.com/rust-random/rand/blob/master/rand_core/CHANGELOG.md
This new version makes using rand_core on wasm seamless (thanks to the update of getrandom to v0.2)
The crate compiles well with this PR, but since some `rand_core` traits are publicly exposed in this crate's API, this is strictly speaking a breaking change.
